Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Determinants of Welfare State Spending

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES#: 1003012
PI: Jill S. Quadagno
Co-PI: Kaiser Russell Shekha
Florida State University

This project explores welfare state spending in Latin American countries. There are two research questions. First, how do Intergovernmental Organizations (IGOs), International Nongovernmental Organizations (INGOs), and ratification of human rights treaties affect social security and welfare, health, and education spending in 18 Latin American countries from 1980-2000? Second, what are the effects of religious political parties? The study builds on traditional welfare state theories, while also integrating new approaches such as World Society theory and human rights research. It is anticipated that Catholic and Protestant political parties will be positively associated with welfare state spending. It is also expected that while INGOs and human rights treaties will be positively associated with social spending, IGOs will be negatively associated with welfare state spending. This study highlights the importance of political globalization and increasingly global human rights norms in determining the outcomes of domestic social spending. Additionally, research on Latin American social spending and policy will be useful in classrooms, allowing students to compare the linkages of social spending and local and international politics between regions like Latin America, the United States, and Western Europe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF Sociology Program dissertation improvement grant successfully espoused numerous intellectual merits and broader impacts to society. Intellectually, the primary research activity was the collection of high quality universal human rights, international civil society, political, economic, demographic, and social data on 26 Latin American and Caribbean nations from 1960-2010. Methodologically, this project employed cutting edge statistical techniques that are particularly well suited to handle these sorts of pooled, time-series data that compare across nations and over time. These data were used to examine the impacts of universal human rights as a new political power resource on social security and welfare, health, and education spending levels and national income inequality rates across 18 Latin American nations from 1980-2008. This project also draws on classical welfare state theories that emphasize national political power balances, the national economy, economic globalization, population shifts and changes, and societal factors such as education and ethnic diversity to predict variation in social spending levels and income inequality. The broader impacts of this project include the following benefits to society. This study improves the understanding of forces that impact social spending and income inequality overtime in Latin America.  This is important because it allows national political parties, international civil society organizations, and global governance institutions to better understand their role in affecting domestic social spending levels as well as national income inequality rates. Adding to that, this study highlights the importance of the political globalization of universal human rights norms as new political power resources at the national level in determining domestic social spending and income inequality. Finally, this study is a test-case for previous theoretical development in welfare state studies by applying the theories to an understudied region of the world, allowing for future comparison between regions of less developed countries and regions of higher development.

The most substantively important findings are that human rights treaty ratification and National Human Rights Institutions presences have mostly positive effects on social security and welfare, health, and education spending levels in 18 Latin American nations from 1980-2008. Regardless of any nuances, it is clear that embracing universal human rights enables Latin American nations to move towards the fulfillment of their obligations to protect and promote the social rights of their peoples, regardless of citizenship status. Another set of major findings show that embracing universal human rights as a new political power resource through treaty ratifications leads to lower national income inequality measured using the GINI coefficient in these same 18 Latin American nations from 1980-2008. Other important findings include the effects of traditional national political power resources on social spending levels and national income inequality. Finally, the national economy, industrialization, neoliberal globalization, demographic transitions, and societal conditions all show some associations with social security and welfare, health, and education spending levels. They also show impacts on national income inequality. These important predictors draw on classical welfare state theories and suggest their continued, albeit inconsistent, effects on the welfare state and inequality in contemporary Latin America.

During the course of this NSF project the CO-PI, Dr. K. Russell Shekha, was able to extend and expand existing publicly available data sets funded in part by the NSF focusing on Latin American political and welfare state indicators.
